addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England

31 Au
g
1592 M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
Repulse of
e Ennemie.
Rendring of
Coverden
./

page.lettertext:
fol.209r
May it please yo
r
good L. Heere are letters from
the campe, by w
ch
we are advertised,
at
e army
of
e Enemie is come neere unto
Count Maurice
,
w
t
in lesse then half a leauge, and lodged very
strongly, expecting further forces. The Count ther-
upon doth solicit by his letters, w
ch
he sendes abroad
to every Province, to be presently assisted w
t
all
e aide
at can be spared. It is not muche
at
ei
can spare, but w
at
e contrey shall be able, will be
sent w
t
all diligence: aswel to give him greater
strength, if
e Enemie should charge him, as to as-
sure their frontier places, while
e siege doth con-
tinue. In effect it is thought,
at there are, or
will be shortly, accounting horse and foote together,
between ten and eleven thousand. The
states
at are heere, and likewise
e
Councel,
w
ch
continueth at
Swol,
about two daies jorney from
the campe, as greatly troubled w
t
this mater:
e more a great deale, for
at Count Maurice in
this siege, hath taken contrary courses to their spe-
cial directions. The chiefetaines of
e Enemie are men of fame, and knowen expe-
rience,
at
Count Hohenlo
excepted, we have none
of like account: so as most men are persuaded,
that both for their credit, and for
e rescuing of
Coevoerden, they will not part from o
r
campe, w
t
out geving some attempt, to trie
e courage, and
valo
r
, and conduct of Count Maurice.
I am buisied at this present, to procure a pardon
of
e states, for
e 53 English sea men, w
ch
are in
prison for piracie in
Enchusen
and
Amsterdam,
and for whome yo
r
L. hath written very lately unto me.
fol.209v
Howe I have proceeded, and w
at
I have obtened,
I should but trouble yo
w
w
t
rehersall, not having
brought
e mater to a final resolution. They
were all of them condemned, before yo
r
letter
came unto me, but yet I hope this intercession,
will enlarge
e greater multitude.
At this very instant, and at
e writing heerof,
we have letters from
e campe,
at
e 28 of this
moneth, about 4 of
e clocke in
e morning,
e
Enemie came upon us w
t
a wonderfull furie, and
brake into o
r
trenches, but was valiantly re-
pulsed w
t
e slaughter of many Spaniardes, w
ch
had
e vantgard of
e troupes, and w
t
e losse
among o
rs
of one onely man.
Count William
in
e conflict receaved some hurt, but w
t
out any
danger: and
e Enemie is retired, but whe-
ther it is not signified. For
e l
re
s were
written by some
at were present, and for hast
of sending first, omitted many particularities:
w
ch
I thought notw
t
standing, might deserve to
be reported in suche sort as we have it.
And
so I take my humble leave. From
e Hage
Au
g
31 1592.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
